Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Microparasite-Macroparasite Interactions: Dynamics of Co-infection and Implications for Disease Control
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Infection of hosts by multiple parasite species is the norm rather than the exception in most natural populations, yet studies of parasite dynamics largely focus on single parasites interacting with single hosts. Fundamental principles of immunology suggest that co-infection of hosts by microparasites (bacteria, viruses, protozoa) and macroparasites (helminths) should have important effects on disease dynamics. For example, exposure to macroparasites may increase host susceptibility to and progression of important microparasitic diseases such as AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria in humans. The central goal of this study is to investigate the consequences of microparasite-macroparasite interactions for patterns of disease at three distinct levels of biological organization: individuals, populations and species. To achieve this goal, African buffalo (Syncerus caffer) co-infected with bovine tuberculosis (BTB, Mycobacterium bovis) and gastrointestinal nematodes will be used as a model system to investigate individual-level patterns of infection and parasite population dynamics. Specifically, a combination of field and captive studies and mathematical modeling will be used to assess patterns of infection and immunity in these free-ranging animals, understand the effects of nematode treatment on BTB transmission, and examine the reciprocal effects of BTB on nematodes. Scaling up from this system, a comprehensive database of parasites and pathogens infecting wild mammals and humans will then be used to investigate the effect of helminths on the distribution of microparasitic diseases across populations and species. In combination, these analyses will reveal how within-host immunological interactions between micoparasites and macroparasites shape patterns of disease in natural host populations and among species. Broader impacts of this study include training of multiple graduate students, undergraduate students and paraprofessionals; application of study results to the management of an ecologically and economically important wildlife disease; and active collaboration with the public health community to understand the utility of using helminth control as a tool for combating microparasitic diseases in humans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Infection of hosts by multiple parasite species is the norm rather than the exception in most natural populations, yet studies of parasite dynamics largely focus on single parasites interacting with single hosts. Fundamental principles of immunology suggest that co-infection of hosts by microparasites (bacteria, viruses, protozoa) and macroparasites (helminths) should have important effects on disease dynamics. For example, exposure to macroparasites may increase host susceptibility to and progression of important microparasitic diseases such as AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria in humans.

The central goal of this study was to investigate the consequences of microparasite-macroparasite interactions for patterns of disease at three distinct levels of biological organization: individuals, populations and species. To achieve this goal, African buffalo (Syncerus caffer) co-infected with bovine tuberculosis (BTB, Mycobacterium bovis) and gastrointestinal worms were studied as a model system to investigate individual-level patterns of infection and parasite population dynamics.

Specifically, a combination of field studies and mathematical modeling was used to assess patterns of infection and immunity in these free-ranging animals,  and understand the effects of deworming treatment on BTB transmission. We conducted a four-year field experiment in which 100 buffalo were treated with a long-lasting deworming drug, which drastically reduced their burden of gastro-intestinal nematodes. Another 100 buffalo were left untreated, and all of these animals were captured every six months to measure their immunity and infections. We found that de-worming did not reduce the risk of buffalo becomeing infected with BTB; but BTB-positive buffalo had far better chances of long-term survival if they were de-wormed. Ironically, this individual-level benefit of deworming may come at the cost of increased spread of BTB at the population level, because BTB-infected animals are remaining in the population longer and may thus transmitinfection to others.

We also investigated how BTB, which is a non-native disease in African buffalo (originally from European cattle), affects other diseases that the buffalo carry. BTB strongly exacerbated the risk of acquiring Rift Valley fever (RVF) virus, as well as bovine brucellosis. In addition, BTB-positive buffalo that did become infected with these diseases suffered increased clinical consequences: abortion rates due to RVF were drastically higher in BTB-positive buffalo, and mortality rates increased in buffalo co-infected with BTB and brucellosis.

Scaling up from the buffalo system,we investigated the effect of helminths on the distribution of microparasitic diseases across primate species. We found that primate species with higher overall helminth prevalence harbored more species of intracellular microparasites; concordant with the idea that gasto-intestinal worms facilitate invasion of the host by viral and bacterial pathogens.

Broader impacts of this study include training of five graduate students, including two from South Africa, five undergraduate students and six veterinary students. We also created an archive of blood and tissue samples from our study buffalo, along with detailed information on each animal.  The archive is available to other researchers upon request and is currently being used by South African, British, and US researchers for further studies in disease ecology and genetics. We collaborated directly with wildlife managers and veterinarians, ensuring dissemination of our findings to relevant stakeholders. In addition, we presented our findings in scientific journals, and at a range of scientific and policy oriented national and international meetings.
